acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, Shopify collects sales tax from customers at checkout based on your store's tax settings, but merchants are responsible for filing returns and remitting these collected funds to state and local governments.

mainEntity.name: How is Shopify different from Amazon on this?

acceptedAnswer.text: Amazon is a marketplace, they remit the tax for you. Shopify is a platform for your own store, so it just collects the money and you have to remit it yourself. The responsibility is totally different.

mainEntity.name: What info does Shopify use to calculate tax?

acceptedAnswer.text: The customer's shipping address. That's pretty much it. If it's wrong, the tax will be wrong.

mainEntity.name: What do I do after Shopify collects the tax?

acceptedAnswer.text: You file and you remit. That's your whole job. You use the data from Shopify's reports to fill out the state's forms and send them the money you collected. On time. Every time.

@graph.name: Nexus
@graph.description: A connection to a state that means you have to collect tax there

@graph.name: Remittance
@graph.description: The act of sending the collected tax money to the state

@graph.name: Seller of Record
@graph.description: The business entity legally responsible for tax collection and remittance

@graph.name: Economic Nexus
@graph.description: Tax obligation triggered by sales volume or transaction count, typically $100,000 in sales OR 200 separate transactions per year

@graph.name: Marketplace Facilitator
@graph.description: A platform that collects and remits sales tax on behalf of sellers, like Amazon or Shopify's Shop channel
